Posts.Content: ek25 wrote: I was diagnosed with DCIS in my left breast after a routine mammo in April.  I've been on a clinical study with my surgeon, taking Tamoxifen to see if any of the "noise" of DCIS could be cleared up prior to surgery so they could get clean margins.  As part of the study, I had an initial MRI prior to taking any Tamoxifen and then at one month of taking it.  There was a small spot that lit up on the initial MRI, but because it was right next to my original biopsy site, she thought it might be a hematoma and suggested we watch it for a month and see if it lit up on the second MRI.  It did light up, but was smaller.  A month later, they called me to have me come in for a checkup to monitor the spot.  They tried an ultrasound and couldn't see it at all.  (The spot is about 5mm). So, they sent me for an MRI-guided biopsy this past Tuesday.  I just got the results today and was told that they found DCIS in the biopsy, but they also found some invasive cells.  Since the pathology report is only preliminary, they don't have any of the grading for me yet.  My DCIS was ER/PR+, can I expect that the invasive will be the same?  She said next steps are to schedule me for a lumpectomy and a sentinel node biopsy.   If the sentinel node is clean, does that mean I don't need any axillary biopsy and that I'm probably in line for radiation and tamoxifen?  If the sentinel nodes are not clean, then what?  Axillary?  Does the fact that the sentinel node has never lit up on the MRI bode well for any involvement? Does size of the tumor have anything to do with the likelihood of it having spread?  I thought so, but I've seen women on here with <1cm IDC who had metastasis.   Coming to terms with the original DCIS diagnosis was hard enough, but what's given me strength up until now was that it was in situ.  Now that that has changed, I'm completely terrified once again.  Not for myself, but for my kids.  Anyone who had a similar situation and is willing to weigh in, please do.  I need some comfort right now. Thanks.  Dx 4/4/2012, DCIS, <1cm, Stage 0, Grade 2, 0/0 nodes, ER+/PR+ Hormonal Therapy 5/1/2012 Dx 7/31/2012, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Surgery 8/14/2012 Lumpectomy: Left Surgery 10/9/2012 Lumpectomy: Left Surgery 12/11/2012 Mastectomy: Left, Right Surgery 3/22/2013 Reconstruction (left); Reconstruction (right) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: DCIS diagnosis just changed to IDC ek25 voraciousreader

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2012 05:27PM ek25 wrote: BLinthedese, Thanks for your note.  A lot of positives in it, which, of course, is what I'm looking to hear at this point.  This disease is so frustrating because it never seems final - I mean, knowing exactly what it is that you have.  I knew there was a chance that there might be some invasive element with DCIS, but since I've had like 25 mammogram shots since the original diagnosis, including many that were concentrated shots right around the biopsy site (where the IDC was) and nothing showed up on US, that DCIS was all that I had.   This is a very frightening time for me, you're right.  I almost think doctors do us a disservice by telling us what we have, but leaving us to figure out exactly what that means.  I want a roadmap, decision chart, whatever, you know?
Posts.Title: DCIS diagnosis just changed to IDC ek25 voraciousreader

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2012 11:21PM ek25 wrote: Abby, I'm sorry to hear about your diagnosis.  I went for my routine mammo in March and they found calcifications.  I went back, had a biopsy and got the DCIS diagnosis.  No lumps, no masses, nothing.  For the past two months, I've been on a clinical study where I'm taking Tamoxifen to see if it can "clear up the noise" in my breast such that when surgery is required, they can hopefully get clean margins on a lumpectomy.  As part of the study, I was asked to do an MRI prior to taking it, and then again at one month after taking it.  There was a small spot (<5mm) on my MRI that lit up with the initial and my surgeon said it could be related to a hematoma from the initial biopsy site since it was right next to it.  She was hoping it would disappear at the end of the first month, but it didn't.  They called me back in to try to Ultrasound the area and see if they could find it, but they couldn't.  So, they sent me for an MRI-guided biopsy yesterday and I too am awaiting the results.  As with all things related to this crummy diagnosis, I am hoping for the best, but expecting the worst.   I have three kids, 8, 6, and 3 and I honestly think this diagnosis would be easier to take if I didn't have them.  Like another poster said, they are my babies, my loves.  I don't think of myself in any of this, but about them.  These last 3 months have definitely taught me a lesson that life is precious.  I enjoy every day with them because I don't know if I'll be on this planet for 5 more years or 50.   It's true what they say that time heals all wounds.  As time has passed, I've found it's easier to get beyond the initial diagnosis.  But every time you go in for another test or procedure and become a human pin cushion, you're rudely reminded of what it is that you have.  I am hoping that your MRI biopsy turns out okay, as does mine.  As far as the mastectomy vs. lumpectomy, I personally think I will opt for the lumpectomy if it's on the table for me.  This is such an emotional time and an emotional diagnosis, I think it's easy to jump to the conclusion that we should just get rid of the source, but from what I've read on this site and heard from others, mastectomy is no picnic and has a whole host of problems.  My thinking has always been, if the lumpectomy is available to me, I'll take it.  If this comes back, I still have the mastectomy to consider later on.   Best wishes to you during your wait.
Posts.Title: I am so scared Abby20 kathleen1966

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2012 04:53AM ek25 wrote: Thanks to everyone who weighed in here to provide information.  As always, it is reassuring to hear others' stories of survival. It gives me courage and makes it seem just a tiny bit less terrifying.
Posts.Title: DCIS diagnosis just changed to IDC ek25 voraciousreader

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2012 04:34PM ek25 wrote: Hi - I am brand new to this site.  I went for my routine mammo on 3/15 and was called back for enhanced magnification views.  I did that and they told me they'd seen calcifications in my left breast.  One spot, not tightly clustered, but also not scattered.  They had difficulty finding them the second time since they were so faint.  Said they had some irregular borders.  They gave me a BIRAD rating of 4a and put me in the indeterminate category.  I pushed them to get my biopsy scheduled as soon as possible and had it today.  Honestly, although I am sick with worry, the biopsy was probably one of the easiest, most painless things I've ever done.  They said I'd get the results in 2-3 business days, so I'm probably looking at next Wednesday as a worst case scenario.  I understand that as a BIRAD 4a, the statistics say there's a 3-10% chance it's cancer, so the odds are definitely in my favor, but I can't stop thinking that someone has to be the 10%. Like the others here, I'm overwhelmed with anxiety and worry, can't sleep, don't eat regularly, etc...The only person I've told about this is my husband, who, while he tries hard to relate, can't. I hope that anyone who is either awaiting a biopsy or the results of one hears good news over the next few days.
Posts.Title: Nodules & Calcifications Momof6 1osugrl

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2013 11:11AM ek25 wrote: Hi Shira, In response to your question about whether to go for a lumpectomy or mastectomy, at the end of the day, it's really your choice and your gut reaction to the amount of stress (induced from your decision) that you're willing to deal with.  If there is a medically necessary reason to perform a mastectomy after a lumpectomy (for instance, if they did not get clean margins), then your insurance should pay for it. Take a look at my profile below.  Unlike you, I was originally diagnosed with DCIS and then they found a very small invasive tumor lurking in the DCIS.  Because the DCIS was scattered throughout my breast, my original lumpectomy was unsuccessful getting clean margins.  That was followed by a lumpectomy/breast reduction.  Again, unclean margins.  At that point, I opted for a bi-lateral mastectomy and decided to put an end to being a human pin cushion.  With regard to other treatments - I was able to entirely avoid radiation because of the mastectomy.  I do, however, take Tamoxifen.  I think most doctors will tell you that it is necessary to prevent either a recurrence at the scar site or kill any rogue cells that may have escaped. Best wishes to you and your surgery.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed and Lumpectomy early next week Shira CTMOM1234

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2012 08:15AM ek25 wrote: Teeballmom, I read your post and it made me cry!  I don't even know you and you're making me cry.  I too was recently (3 weeks ago) diagnosed with bc and have small kids.  I worry about all the same things you do that you mentioned. I think it's human nature to want to catastrophize things when they happen.  I know my mind automatically goes to the worst case scenario.  It took 3 weeks to get my appt with a surgeon and I met with him yesterday.  In those 3 weeks, I'd done tons of research and had thought I understood my diagnosis and had neatly tucked away my emotions.  Not true.  Yesterday all the fears came flooding back.  Just walking into a place called the "Breast Cancer Center" was daunting.  Seeing women sitting in wheelchairs and walking around with wigs on made me shake.  I wanted to run out the door and never come back.  I left the dr.'s office, headed to the car and sat inside and just wept and wept.  To top off a bad emotional day, it was my husband's birthday yesterday and as we're eating cake, he starts talking about all the things he's grateful for and his family, etc...I had to excuse myself from the cake eating and go upstairs and weep some more.   This whole journey just stinks and so far, there isn't one single part of it that's any good.  The kids want to know why my eyes are red, if I'm feeling okay, what's wrong mommy....I hope for both of us that things get better from here.  I'll be thinking of you.
Posts.Title: Today is an emotionally bad day :( teeballmom ByFaith

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2013 12:36AM ek25 wrote: Hi Kiko, I went back and read your posts to familiarize myself with your situation.  Yes, I was at an earlier stage.  I was originally diagnosed with DCIS.  It was in a couple of different places in my breast.  When they did the MRI, they saw a spot, but didn't think it was anything.  I had it biopsied and it was a 5mm invasive tumor.  From what I understand, invasive tumors tend to be centrally located in one tumor and DCIS tends to be spread throughout the breast.  Because of that, I had the first lumpectomy and they didn't get clean margins because of the DCIS.  The invasive part was gone with clean margins, it was the DCIS.  So, my second surgery was to get clean margins and again, they got clean margins at the lumpectomy site, but they also did a breast reduction and when the plastic surgeon came in to reshape the breast, he took some tissue out and there was DCIS in it and the margins were dirty.  At that point, I said, 'enough, I'm done'.  With the reduction surgery, I had gone through 80% of a mastectomy and felt like I didn't get the end result of having healthy breasts.  So, I opted for a bilateral and to be honest, I've never regretted it.  It is a way more difficult surgery than the lumpectomy to recover from, but I have the type of personality where I don't want to have regrets.  The only way I can go through my life with a diagnosis like this is to know that I did everything possible to make sure it didn't come back.  Like you, I have always been healthy.  Yes, I had my kids later than I probably should have, but I was a vegetarian for 25 years, never smoked, hardly ever drank, breast fed all three kids, etc, etc...I'm not big for going down the path of "Why me?" though.  It is what it is and no amount of second guessing is going to change the fact that I have cancer.  It's in the past and now I need to focus on how to live the most productive life I can. I opted for the bilateral mastectomy because I didn't want to sit in that chair and be told I had cancer ever again.  My surgeon said that I could opt for a lumpectomy with radiation and hope that the radiation killed any remaining DCIS.  That was a risk I wasn't willing to take.  And, I didn't want mismatched breasts.  Hell, after what I went through, I wanted to make sure they matched...and they do.  I figured I'd used my breasts for what they were intended to do - breastfeed my babies.  The lack of feeling sucks, but you eventually get kind of used to it - never completely used to it.  The upside is, I never have to wear a bra EVER AGAIN!!!  They are perky all the time.  My dear husband said he thought it was a big upgrade from my natural breasts since after 3 babies in 5 years and A LOT of breastfeeding, my boobs didn't look that great.    I wish you all the best, Kiko.  Feel free to private message me if you want to talk further.  And remember, you're going through the absolute worst of it right now.  You will get through this and someday cancer will be a distant memory for all of us.  Stay strong and believe in the future.
Posts.Title: In Total Shock!!!!!!! carissabforlife Kiko

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2013 04:53PM ek25 wrote: I am so sorry to hear everyone's tales in this thread.  As so many have said already, time really does help to heal this disease.  I am always so saddened when I read about such young women like Carissa posting here.  I was not quite as young as Carissa, but young and the mother of three young children, when I was diagnosed last year. I would urge all of you who are young to try to find a support group that's aimed at providing support for women diagnosed at a younger age.  When I was diagnosed, I contacted a support group that was recommended by a friend who'd gone through this prior to my diagnosis.  They had a buddy support network and I asked to be assigned to a buddy.  I specifically asked for someone who was diagnosed at my age and who maybe had children.  What I wanted most to know in those dark, dark days was that people survived this disease.  It felt like such a death sentence!  They assigned me to a 65 year old woman who'd never had kids and who couldn't relate to my situation at all.  And then I found a support group aimed at younger women who, like me, had been frustrated to be sitting in a room full of 70 year old women.  The point of my post is not to disparage older women, but most of us would agree that younger women with children who are pre-menopausal have a different set of circumstances to face. If you can't find one in your area, keep coming to this site for support and answers to your questions and when you are back on your feet, think about maybe starting a support group with other young survivors in your area.  It has made all the difference for me.  In fact, I have begun a series of profiles in my group, profiling young survivors who are years out from their diagnosis.  I hope that other newly diagnosed women can read these profiles and take solace in the fact that women do survive this disease at many different ages.   Best wishes to you all.
Posts.Title: In Total Shock!!!!!!! carissabforlife Kiko
